p: C. fistula leaves were collected from natural habitats, and the identification was done by Dr. Sunita Garg, Chief Scientist and Head, Herbarium Department, National Institute of Science Communication and Information Resources (NISCAIR), New Delhi, India (ref No. NISCAIR/RHMD/Consult/2018/3268-69-5). After collecting it from the field, selected plant materials were washed and air-dried in shade at room temperature. After the leaves were moisture-free, they were grounded separately in an electric grinder. The prepared powder form of plant materials (100 g) was soaked in 500 mL of methanol and placed on a rotary shaker at room temperature for 24 h. The extract was filtered using a Buchner funnel and Whatman filter paper and concentrated to dryness using a rotary evaporator under vacuum at 35 °C. The dried plant extract was stored at −20 °C until used for bioassay.
